parsetree.*:
<root><template><title>RV</title><part><name>type</name>=<value>command

</value></part><part><name index="1"/><value> ofp
</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>

</value></part><part><name>gr1 </name>=<value> Markers

</value></part><part><name>arg</name>=<value> global

</value></part><part><name index="3"/><value> Get type of marker. Note: This function is identical to [[getMarkerType]]. See [[cfgMarkers]] for a list of standard markers.

</value></part><part><name index="4"/><value> [[String]] <ext><name>nowiki</name><attr/><inner>=</inner><close></nowiki></close></ext> '''markerType''' markerName

</value></part><part><name>p1</name>=<value> markerName: [[String]]

</value></part><part><name index="5"/><value> [[String]]. See [[cfgMarkers]].
		  
</value></part><part><name>x1</name>=<value> <code>[[if]] ('''markerType''' "Marker1" == "Empty") [[then]] {[[hint]] "Marker1 is not an icon!"}</code>

</value></part><part><name>seealso</name>=<value> [[cfgMarkers]], [[setMarkerType]], [[setMarkerTypeLocal]]
</value></part></template>

<dl class="command_description">
<comment><!-- Note Section BEGIN -->
</comment>
<dd class="notedate">Posted on March 17, 2014</dd>
<dt class="note">[[User:Waffle SS.|Waffle SS.]]</dt>
<dd class="note"> Using markerType is a good method to determine if a string is a valid marker name, unless the marker type isn't set. <code>if (markerType "mark1" != "") then {hint "valid marker"}</code>
<BR><BR>

<comment><!-- Note Section END -->
</comment></dl>
